title: Welcome
content: Blog features are powered by the blog plugin. Simply add files to the blog directory. It supports tags as well! Delete the whole directory if you don't want the blog features. As simple as that!

title: Syntax
content: ABS (value) Copy

title: Arguments
content: value – The cell or number of which you want the absolute value of.

title: Example
content: Consider a scenario where you want to calculate the absolute difference between demand and inventory. The values for demand, inventory and the absolute difference are shown in the table below. Parameter	Week 1	Week 2	Week 3	Week 4Demand	110	95	75	78 Inventory	85	70	100	80 Absolute Difference	25	25	25	2 Absolute difference is calculated as: ABS (Demand - Inventory) Copy

title: Excel Equivalent
content: ABS

title: Toggle the sign of values in a row
Syntax
content: AND ( logical_test1, [logical_test2], ... ) Copy

title: Arguments
content: logical_test1 – The first condition to be evaluated. This is a required argument. logical_test2, … – The additional conditions to be evaluated. These are optional arguments.

title: Return value
content: Either True or False.

title: Remarks
content: The AND function accepts multiple conditions.

title: Example
content: Consider a scenario in which if the number of licenses is greater than 500 and usage period is greater than 24 months, then the price should be $20 else $25. To achieve this, the formula should be IF(AND(Num_of_Licenses>500,Duration<24),20,25) Copy

title: Excel Equivalent
content: AND

title: Edit Cell (Report Cell and Static Cell)
Syntax

title: Arguments

title: Example
content: To round each value in 'COLUMN1' to the highest multiple value of column 'Function', use the formula as: CEILING(COLUMN1,Function) Copy COLUMN1	Function	Result10	4	12.00 2.5	1	3.00 0.156	0.01	0.16 36	7	42.00 -5.5	1	-5.00

title: Undo/Redo or Reset when things go wrong
Syntax
content: IN(value,List) Copy

title: Arguments
content: value: The value to be validated. This value can be numeric, string, function, or a column reference.List: An array of items. This list can be a combination of numbers/string/function or column reference.

title: Returns
content: 'True' or 'False'

title: Remarks
content: The IN function can be combined with the IF function.

title: Example
content: The function returns 25 if value of the column 'Region' is either 'West' or 'East', otherwise it returns 30. IF(IN(Region, ["West","East"]),25, 30) Copy

title: Syntax
content: ISNUMBER(value) Copy

title: Arguments
content: value: A Cell or a number

title: Example
content: To check every value in a column(Employee_id) is numeric, use the formula as: ISNUMBER(Employee_id) Copy To set the value "0" if the expression (AC-PY)/PY does not evaluates to a number, use the formula as: IF(ISNUMBER((AC-PY)/PY), (AC-PY)/PY , 0) Copy

title: Returns
content: AC-PY/PY if the value is a number else returns 0.

title: Row Aggregation Type - Formula Vs Sum
content: To apply row aggregation functions in Inforiver visual, you can create Visual columns and select the appropriate row aggregation method. Select the Advanced tab.From the Customize ribbon bar category, select the drop-down under Insert column.Select Visual Column. Insert a new Visual column Let's consider an example where you want to calculate the percentage variance of 2 columns. Create a new visual column that calculates the average of '2020 Actuals' and '2019 Actuals'. In the Visual Column window on the right, enter a Column name.Enter the variance formula using the row ids in the Formula box.Select the Row aggregation type as formula.Select Apply. Visual column of row aggregation type - 'formula' The result in the row aggregation cell is the accurate value for the variance calculation. In other case, if you select the Row aggregation type as sum: Visual column of row aggregation type - 'sum' The resultant row aggregated value is calculated as the sum of the values of the rows and not as variance of the 2 actuals; which can result in an inaccurate calculation of % Change in this case.

title: Before you begin
content: In the Fields navigation pane on the right-hand side, select the fields from your dataset.In the Rows tab of the Visualization navigation pane on the right, re-order the rows and columns fields.The field selected in the Values (AC) section will be your columns in the visual.

title: Formula calculation based on Column Indexing
content: Consider an example where you need to calculate Quarterly variance in a hierarchial dataset. Select Advanced > Insert column > Visual Column. Enter a Column name, Type as "Custom Calculation". In the Formula box, refer the columns listed in the Values (AC) field and enter any formula. The basic syntax is: AC<num>_<index>, where AC<num> is the sequence number of the listed column name(s), starting with AC, AC1, AC2 .. ACn.<index> is position number of columns listed in the visual, starting from 1, 2, 3 .. n. Q1 and Q2 variance calculation based on column indexes AC_1 refers to the column from Qtr 1, and AC_2 refers to the column from Qtr 2. Select the Row aggregation type as Formula.Select Apply. The highlighted column displays the result of the formula on the columns that you referenced as indexes. As you add/remove other columns, the above formula will still be valid as indicated below: Formula calculation valid on changing column hierarchy

title: Further example
content: To calculate a variance between the sum of "Sales Forecast (AC)" for all the quarters and the sum of "Sales Budget (AC1)" for all quarters, use the formula as: Visual Column Formula (AC_1+AC_2+AC_3+AC_4) - (AC1_1+AC1_2+AC1_3+AC1_4) Copy

title: Syntax
content: OR ( logical_test1, [logical_test2], ... ) Copy

title: Arguments
content: logical_test1 – The first condition to be evaluated. This is a required argument.logical_test2, … – The additional conditions to be evaluated. These are optional arguments.

title: Return value
content: Either True or False.

title: Remarks
content: The OR function accepts multiple conditions.

title: Example
content: Consider a scenario in which if the number of licenses is greater than 500 or the usage period is greater than 24 months, then the price should be $20 else $25. To achieve this, the formula should be: IF(OR(Num_of_Licenses>500,Duration<24),20,25) Copy

title: Excel Equivalent
content: OR

title: Syntax
content: IF( logical_test, value_if_true, value_if_false ) Copy

title: Arguments
content: logical_test: The condition to be evaluated.value_if_true: The value to be returned if the condition is met. The value may be numeric, string, column name or another function.value_if_false: The value to be returned if the condition is not met. The value may be numeric, string, column name or another function.

title: Return Value
content: Either value_if_true or value_if_false.

title: Remarks
content: Returns Blank when the formula is misspelled. The IF function returns an Error (ERR!) in any of the following cases: Either value_if_true or value_if_false or both arguments are missing.The argument value_if_true or value_if_false are not of numeric or string or column data type.Use of incorrect operator in logical_test.

title: Example
content: Consider the Revenue and Cost of Goods Sold to follow the trend as shown below: Parameter	Jan	Feb	Mar	Apr	May	Jun	Jul	AugRevenue	100	124	137	0	23	45	52	36 Cost of Goods Sold	25	25	25	25	25	25	25	25 Now, Gross Profit Margin can be computed using the IF function as: (Revenue-Cost of Goods Sold)/Revenue. In case, Revenue has period value of 0, Gross Profit Margin should return 0. To achieve this, the formula should be: IF(Revenue==0,0,(Revenue-Cost of Goods Sold)/Revenue) Copy The result of the above formula is shown below: Parameter	Jan	Feb	Mar	Apr	May	Jun	Jul	AugGross Profit Margin	75%	80%	82%	0	9%	44%	52%	31%

title: Excel Equivalent
content: IF Tip Use SWITCH function instead of nesting multiple IF functions.

title: Syntax
content: ISNAN (value1,value2) Copy

title: Arguments
content: value1 – The cell reference that is to be checked for error values.value2 – The value which is to replace the error values.

title: Return value

title: Example
content: Consider the rows Total Cost and No. of units to have the periods values as shown below Period	Jan	Feb	Mar	Apr	May	Jun	Jul	Aug	Sep	Oct	Nov	DecTotal Cost	100	150	200	100	300	250	300	0	225	300	0	300 No. of units	10	15	10	10	15	25	15	0	15	15	0	15 In the below example, Cost per unit is calculated by dividing Total Cost and No. of units. Before applying ISNAN: Period	Jan	Feb	Mar	Apr	May	Jun	Jul	Aug	Sep	Oct	Nov	DecCost per unit	10	10	20	10	20	10	20	#	15	20	#	20 Cost per unit returns Error(#) for Aug and Nov, the error is to be replaced with 0. To achieve this, the formula should be: ISNAN(Total Cost/No. of units,0) Copy Applying applying ISNAN: Period	Jan	Feb	Mar	Apr	May	Jun	Jul	Aug	Sep	Oct	Nov	DecCost per unit	10	10	20	10	20	10	20	0	15	20	0	20

title: Writeback Logs
content: Go to the Configure Writeback page to access the config setup. For each writeback operation that you perform, the logs are maintained in the Logs section with the following details: Writeback Logs Version: Latest writeback version.Started At: Timestamp of when the writeback was triggered.Started By: Name of the username who triggered writeback.Status: Status of the writeback operation. The status message maybe 'Success', 'Failure', or 'Partial Success' ( when one of the destinations failed ). Select any of the version numbers to see the detailed logs for each writeback destination configured. Writeback Log details with export information

title: Example
content: Returns the result of the calculation (AC-PY)/PY if the value is a number else in case of an error it returns 0. IFNA((AC-PY)/PY, 0) Copy

content: Account	Q1	Q2	Q3	Q4Sales Expense	10.1m	14.5m	13.2m	12.4m Marketing Expense	11.3m	12.0m	14.6m	13.2m MAX	11.3m	14.5m	14.6m	13.2m To calculate the maximum of the two expenses in the resultant row 'MAX', the formula should be: MAX(Sales Expense, Marketing Expense) Copy

title: Syntax
content: XOR ( logical_test1, [logical_test2], ... ) Copy

title: Arguments
content: logical_test1 – The first condition to be evaluated. This is a required argument.logical_test2, … – The additional conditions to be evaluated. These are optional arguments.

title: Return value
content: Either True or False

title: Remark
content: The result of XOR is TRUE when the number of TRUE inputs is odd and FALSE when the number of TRUE inputs is even.

title: Example
content: Consider an investment scenario of investing in either stocks or property, but not both. To achieve this, the formula should be:  IF (XOR (stocks, property), invested, not invested). Copy

title: Excel Equivalent
content: XOR

title: Syntax
content: SWITCH ( expression, value1, result1, value2, result2, ... value_n, result_n, [default] ) Copy

title: Arguments
content: expression – The statement to be evaluated.value1, value2, … value_n – The list of values to be compared against the expression.result1, result2, … result_n – The result to be returned if the expression matches with the corresponding value in the argument list.default – The default value to be returned if the expression does not match with any of the values in the argument list. This is an optional argument.

title: Return value
content: Returns the corresponding result when the expression matches with value, default in case there was no match.

title: Remark
content: All result expressions and the else expression must be of the same data type.

title: Example
content: Consider a scenario where you have the rank for Total Sales for different regions and want to assign Sales Commission accordingly. Sales Commission for 1st, 2nd and 3rd regions should be 20%, 15% and 10%. The formula should be: SWITCH(Total Sales – Rank,1,0.2,2,0.15,3,0.1) Copy Account	US	APAC	EMEATotal Sales - Rank	1	3	2 Sales Commission	20%	10%	15% The result is the in the 'Sales Commission' row.

title: Excel Equivalent
content: SWITCH

title: Configure Writeback
content: Select the Export tab from the top ribbon bar. From the Writeback section, select Writeback. Login to configure the writeback settings by selecting Login with Office 365.Once you log in, select Export > Writeback again and now select Configure Writeback for first-time configurations. The Writeback configuration page will be launched from the visual. On the config page, you can edit general settings and view the writeback history logs.

title: General
content: In the general section you can select the series and assign writeback permissions. Configure writeback general page Select Series: Visual series to be exported. You can either Select All or check to select individual series.Permissions: Select the user(s) who can writeback from this report. Select all users in the domain or specify certain users from the same domain. Select Save.

title: Destinations
content: There are 4 writeback destinations supported - Database, OneDrive, SharePoint, and URL. The export format of the writeback for OneDrive, SharePoint, and URL is in CSV format. For destination type database, the export format is in a tabular format. Follow the sections Database and CSV to configure the destinations.

title: Perform Writeback
content: Once you configure the writeback settings, from the Export tab select Writeback.  In the Confirm destinations pop-up, select Yes, Writeback. Writeback performed for the configured destinations

title: OneDrive
content: For OneDrive integration, you must sign-in to your oneDrive account and enter the folder path where you want to save the reports. Select Connect and enter your user credentials, and accept the permissions request.In the Path field, select Browse.In the Select Folder pop-up window, select a folder name and then select OK.In the Writeback File Name field, enter a name for your writeback filename. If you perform multiple writebacks with the same name, the filename will be overwritten and replaced with the latest file. OneDrive configuration Select Save.

title: SharePoint
content: Select Connect.Enter SharePoint Domain Name as tenantname.sharepoint.com in the Domain Name field.Select OK. ` SharePoint configuration Upon successfully connecting to the SharePoint domain, enter the following details: Site Name: Name of the SharePoint site that you want to connect to.Drive: SharePoint document library.Folder: Folder within your document library.Data File Name: Name for the exported data file. Select Save.

title: URL
content: Enter a Web URL. You may also add Headers details. URL configuration Select Save.

title: Export format
content: Below is a sample export in the CSV format: CSV sample export format Following are the columns in the export format: Field name	Description<Row and Column Fields>	Dynamically generated row and column fields (hierarchies) for the visual Value Column Name	All series names being used in the report Value	This column will have the value corresponding to the ‘Value Column Name’. Last Updated Date	When Cell editing is done for a value, this field captures the last updated date and timestamp for that value. Source	Represents the type of column. The column types are: 'Native', 'Visual Column', 'Visual measure', 'Static column', 'Static row', 'Calculated rows', 'Headers', and 'Comments'. IR Writeback User	Name of the user who does the writeback. IR Writeback Timestamp	Date timestamp of the writeback. IR Writeback Version	Version number of the latest writeback export.

title: Visual Keyboard Shortcuts

title: Supported Databases
content: You can currently writeback to 3 databases, namely Postgres, MySQL, and Microsoft SQL Server.

title: Settings
content: For each database configuration enter the following database properties: Database configuration Following are the configuration settings available: Database Type: Postgres, MySQL, or Microsoft SQL ServerHost/IP: Host or IP address of the databasePort: Endpoint port number of the database Username: Username of the database Password: Password Database: Database name Schema: Database schema Enable SSL: Check to enable SSL connection Table Name: Table name to insert the writeback rows  Select Save to save your configuration settings.

title: Columns created in the writeback table
content: Following are the columns in the database export format: Column name	Descriptionir_id	Primary Key : auto-increment integer. <Row and Column Fields>	Dynamically generated row and column fields (hierarchies) for the visual value_column_name	All series names being used in the report value	This column will have the value corresponding to the ‘value_column_name’. last_updated	When Cell editing is done for a value, this field captures the last updated date and timestamp for that value. source	Represents the type of column. The column types are: 'Native', 'Visual Column', 'Visual measure', 'Static column', 'Static row', 'Calculated rows', 'Headers', and 'Comments'. ir_comments	This column will have the Comment corresponding to the ‘Value Column Name’. Comments will be saved in JSON format. ir_writeback_user	Name of the user who does the writeback. ir_writeback_timestamp	Date timestamp of the writeback. ir_writeback_version	Version number of the latest writeback export.

title: Examples
content: The following examples show sample visual data that is used to writeback to an external database. note Column Header level comments will be sent as new row with source = Headers and value_column_name = Column Name + "Column Header" (For eg: for column AC the value column name would be 'AC Column Header').Row Header level comment will be sent as a new row, with source = Headers, value_column_name = Row Header.Cell level comments will be part of the same row that represents the cell.Comment column will be sent as new row with source= Comments and value_column_name = Comments.If you alter the visual columns, you must also alter the table.

title: Example 1: Visual Measure column and annotations
content: Visual Measure column and comments Columns 'AC' and 'PY' are native columns.Column 'Ac-PY' is a visual measure column.The bold row 'All' is the 'row grand total' row. The above data is written in the writeback table as shown below: Visual columns and comments inserted as rows in the table. Column and comments mappings from the visual into the database: Column grand total value for AC = 1176100Column grand total value for PY = 1264910Column grand total value for Ac-PY = -88,810.00Sample column header commentSample row header commentSample cell level comment

content: 'Product 4' is a Calculated row The values for 'Product 4' is written in the writeback table with 'source' marked as 'Static Row'. Calculated row inserted as a static row

content: The cell value for 'Central > AC' is edited for 'Product1'. Cell editing The above value is inserted as highlighted in the below screenshot. Edited cell inserted as a static row Note the edited date and timestamp updated in the 'last_updated' column.

title: Export Custom Theme/Configs
content: Select the Advanced tab on the ribbon and select Export/Import. Export/Import drop-down menu list You can choose to export the visual theme settings or configurations. Export Theme: Design changes (colors and formattings) settings applied in the visual.Export Config: Visual configurations such as navigation, scaling, number format, conditional format, and templates. Select the export type as "Export Theme" or "Export Config": Exporting the visual's configurations Right Click on the the .json file name and select Save Link As option.Navigate to your desired storage location and select Save. Your visual data will be downloaded in a json format.

title: JSON Theme File Format
content: The most basic JSON file has following fields: Field/Section Name	Descriptiontype	Type of data export. '1' is for theme file, and '2' for a config file. chartSettings	Visual chart layout type and settings. chartTitle	Title field settings annotation	Annotation configurations headerOption	Table Header settings inforiverProps	Inforiver global visual formatting configurations. subTotals	Row and Column level sub totals setting to true or false. export	Export settings such as export type, scaling, page size etc. metadata	Rows and Columns metadata details. Below is a templated example of the Extended-format JSON file with nested specifications. { "version": 1, "type": 1, "config": [ { "name": "", "properties": { } } { ... } ], "metadata": { "measures": { "": [ { "label": "", "name": "", "role": "" }, ] }, "columns": [], "rows": [ { } ] } } Copy Click to download a sample JSON formatted Configuration fileand Theme file.
